title: Databases & Storage
description: Learn how apps store and retrieve data using databases, from relational SQL tables to flexible NoSQL stores.

content.question: Which type of database organizes data into tables with rows and columns, similar to a spreadsheet?
content.explanation: Relational databases like PostgreSQL and MySQL store data in structured tables with rows (records) and columns (fields). Each table represents an entity (like users or products), and you use SQL to query them.

content.prompt: Write a SQL query to get all users from the 'users' table who are older than 18.

hints: This SQL keyword retrieves data from a table
The name of the table mentioned in the prompt

content.prompt: Match each database type to its best description.

pairs.right: Structured tables with rows and columns
Simple pairs like a dictionary: key maps to a value
Optimized for relationships between connected data

content.prompt: Put these steps in order to design a simple database for a blog app.
items: Identify the main entities (users, posts, comments)
Define the columns/fields for each entity
Choose data types for each column (text, number, date)
Set up relationships between tables (e.g., a post belongs to a user)
Write SQL queries to create the tables
content.explanation: Database design starts with identifying what you need to store, then defining structure, choosing types, connecting related data, and finally creating the tables with SQL.

content.sentence: In a relational database, a _____ is a single entry in a table, while a _____ defines a specific piece of information like 'name' or 'email'.

content.code:
-- Given a 'products' table:
-- | id | name    | price |
-- | 1  | Apple   | 1.50  |
-- | 2  | Banana  | 0.75  |
-- | 3  | Cherry  | 2.00  |

SELECT name FROM products WHERE price < 1.00;
content.explanation: Only Banana has a price less than 1.00 (it costs 0.75). The WHERE clause filters rows, and SELECT name means we only see the name column.

title: DNS & Domains
description: Discover how domain names get translated into IP addresses so your browser can find websites on the internet.

content.question: What is the primary job of the Domain Name System (DNS)?
options: Translate human-readable domain names into IP addresses
Encrypt data sent between your browser and a website
Store website files on a server
content.explanation: DNS acts like the internet's phone book. When you type 'google.com', DNS translates that human-friendly name into a numeric IP address (like 142.250.80.46) so your browser knows which server to contact.

content.prompt: Match each DNS record type to what it does.

pairs.right: Points a domain to an IPv4 address
Creates an alias from one domain to another
Directs email to the correct mail server
Stores text information, often for verification

content.prompt: Put these steps in order: What happens when you type 'www.example.com' into your browser?
items: You type the URL into your browser's address bar
Your browser checks its local cache for the IP address
If not cached, the browser asks a DNS resolver for the IP
The DNS resolver looks up the domain and returns the IP address
Your browser sends an HTTP request to that IP address
The server responds with the web page content
content.explanation: When you visit a website, your browser first needs to find the server's IP address through DNS resolution. It checks its cache first, then asks a DNS resolver. Once it has the IP, it can send the actual web request.

content.sentence: A domain _____ is a company where you purchase and register domain names like 'mysite.com'.

title: CI/CD & Deployment
description: Learn how modern teams automatically test, build, and deploy code so updates reach users quickly and safely.

content.question: What is the main benefit of Continuous Integration (CI)?
options: Automatically testing code changes every time a developer pushes to the repository
Hosting your website on a content delivery network
Writing code faster with AI assistance
Backing up your database every hour
content.explanation: Continuous Integration automatically runs tests and checks every time code is pushed. This catches bugs early before they reach production, ensuring that new changes don't break existing features.

content.prompt: Put these CI/CD pipeline steps in the correct order.
items: Developer pushes code to the Git repository
CI server detects the change and starts the pipeline
Automated tests run against the new code
Code is built into a deployable package
The build is deployed to a staging environment for review
After approval, the build is deployed to production
content.explanation: A typical CI/CD pipeline starts when code is pushed, then automatically tests it, builds it, deploys to staging for verification, and finally pushes to production once approved.

content.prompt: Match each CI/CD concept to its description.

pairs.right: Automatically test and merge code changes frequently
Automatically push approved changes to production
A copy of production used for final testing before release
A series of automated steps that prepare code for deployment

content.sentence: In CI/CD, the _____ environment is where you test changes before releasing them to real users in _____.

questions.question: According to the pipeline, what happens if the tests fail?
options: The code is deployed to production anyway

questions.question: What step comes right before deploying to production?
